params.text:
• Activate learners’ background knowledge, by letting them brainstorm the topic or theme of the reading text, to activate the knowledge that they already have on the topic.
  • If the theme of a listening text is for example on pollution, you can stimulate learners’ background knowledge by first asking them whether they have ever seen discarded plastic bags lying around, or if they have woken up one morning and could smell and see smog in the air. Let them have an informal class discussion on their experiences. Alternatively, you can let them brainstorm the topic pollution.

• Read the title of the listening text to learners, e.g. “One of my worst days” and let them predict what they expect the text might be about. Let them write it down, so that they can say afterwards whether their prediction was on or off target.
  • Read the title and ask them to guess whether it is the title of a poem, song, short story or drama.
  • Another option is to let them listen to the first and the last sentence of a text and let learners predict what the text is about.

panels.title: Predict what text may be about by looking at the title of the text

params.text:
• Explain difficult words that learners will come across in the listening text beforehand. If the text is too difficult because of too many unfamiliar words in it, learners won’t understand and will lose interest.
  • Write difficult words and their meaning on the beard where learners can see them, so that they can refer to these words when they hear them.

panels.title: Deal with key vocabulary that learners may not be familiar with

params.text:
• Before listening to the text, focus them, by asking them to identify the main characters, listen for the main message, listen to identify rhyme and rhythm, listen for bias or stereotyping, listen to remember so that will be able to retell the story in their own words after they have listened, listen to identify the use of synonyms, listen to distinguish facts from allegations, and so on.
  • The text may be listened to more than once and a different question may be set each time.

panels.title: Set a pre-listening question to focus learners’ attention

params.text:
• If you want learners to take notes or follow directions on a map, they must be informed beforehand that they will have to do so and you must make sure that they have pen and paper and the map ready to do so.
  • If learners have to follow instructions, you have to inform them beforehand of the type of activities they will have to perform.
